subject: Re: Is Junit-based testing REALLY possible for commercial software development ?

messageBody:
> The way to solve this problem is to include testing in the planning
> and project features and deadlines accordingly, but for having
been there as
> well, I agree that it's not always possible.

Cedric, I think it is good to think about testing in planning phase. I
guess for a team new to JUnit-based testing, the productivity will be
decreased at the begining. But I have no ideas how much extra effort
it would be. So I may pick a small-sized project to try and find out
from the real coding / testing.

Cheers,
- Frank

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, CÃ©dric Beust â <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> Fascinating questions, Frank :-)
>
> A few thoughts.
>
>
> - Will thorough testing make the project take longer? Of course it
> will. Either in time or in programmers. After all, we are
talking about
> writing more code, so the number of man.months is going to go up as
> well.
>
> The way to solve this problem is to include testing in the planning
> and project features and deadlines accordingly, but for having
been there as
> well, I agree that it's not always possible.
>
> - Using debuggers less might be a good thing *if* the developers find
> bugs faster. I have seen quite a few TDD enthusiasts choose not
to use
> debuggers for dogmatic reasons ("because I read it in a book")
and then
> spend hours writing tests or even println's trying to reproduce a
mysterious
> bug that a breakpoint would have caught in a few minutes.
>
> Again, the solution here is to be pragmatic: you have two tools at
> your disposal (testing and debugger), both with their pros and
cons, and
> you'd be a fool to choose to use only one.
>
> --
> Cedric
> http://testng.org
>
>
